and leadership, I want to leave a lot of time so

105.text:
to strengthen the foundation of your

the challenge of transcending the

and modesty, egotism and altruism,

there is only the timeless continuity, the

by a persistent effort, decade upon decade

and to explore the most distant

what you have that I think makes you a model

about as the best of American higher education

coupled with an emphasis on students,

We expect research institutions

but as many of you know very few institutions

and to really support undergraduates and to

the fact that you have first-rate

who get a chance to get involved

Now, this in New England, and I am from

239.text:
One day we're like Philadelphia,

It depends on the issue, like

We are Southern, and in the South --
in the Deep South we love stories.

And I begin, really, with
a story, a very brief story

259.text: that speaks volumes about my own childhood.

262.text:
You're celebrating the fortieth

266.text:
in your history involving the emphasis on Native

272.text:
one of them co-ed education,

283.text:
And it was in this year that I was a
little 12-year-old in the ninth grade

286.text:
and had no idea -- a little fat kid,
loving math, loving to eat and math,

291.text:
those were my two loves, had no idea

295.text:
about the opportunity to go to better schools,
and that we'd stop using hand-me-down books

300.text:
if we just participated in
this march to show America

304.text: that we knew we deserved a better education.

306.text:
I had no idea I'd spend a week in jail, had no
idea that I'd get a chance to work and bring

311.text:
and take little kids to jail, but the
experience, it was quite an experience.

317.text:
I was afraid -- I was as afraid,
I was not a courageous kid,

319.text:
but I was this fat little kid
loving math, remember that.

322.text:
But I wanted to see what the white
kids were getting in their schools

325.text:
because we'd always been told
their schools were so much better.

327.text:
And we knew the books we got and the things

333.text: And so I was willing to do it.

334.text:
And what the experience taught me
has really shaped my philosophy

340.text:
It taught me that even children really
can think well, and if you empower them

347.text:
to understand their circumstances,
whether they're 12 or young people of 18,

353.text:
quite frankly they can do amazing
things, they absolutely can.

357.text:
And that experience from age 12 has

362.text:
When I think about innovation, and inclusive

366.text:
Number one, innovation has everything to do with
being able to look at the situation as it is,

372.text: and to think about what you'd like it to be.

374.text:
And that means for me being able to look in the

380.text:
UMBC, as we have done over the years and

384.text: To see what's challenging and what's good.

386.text:
To appreciate the strengths but to say, "This is
where we are, but this is where we want to be."

391.text:
And I know that you're going through the

and you know I've heard people say and I've read

the strategic plan, it really is
about what you want to become.

When you think about your
culture it really is who you are.

Your culture has everything to do with the

those things that you really value, what you

those you may not have thought

And I would argue that as we think

we have to look at the culture
of every institution

428.text: to appreciate what is significant there.

For you, clearly, attracting and supporting

436.text: and looking at teaching and learning,

working to help undergraduates

and others who just knew about you,

it was a very positive picture, of course, a

one of the points made was that there is some

between the intellectual side and the

and it's one that people are aware of, and yet

and there are those who would say

There are others who would say
it could be a more serious place

493.text: for undergraduates, as you think about it.

And you determine whether or not,
to what extent that is the case,

I tell it to you because innovation

503.text:
of what you want it to be because

508.text: And we've gone through that same experience

510.text:
and many institutions would

Well, last night, and I said this to several

518.text:
at the hotel, at the inn, and it was
clear that there were some guys last night

523.text:
who had been drinking and
had having a good time.

And they were very loud and I just listened and

I'm not sure this is the best thing

And I did something that was really interesting:

and I said, "Go around and see if there

on a Monday night, and tell them to go

[Laughter] and I tell you that because it could

of a challenge that we all have in higher

553.text:
as we think about what happens in the middle of

557.text:
between the serious and the other side, and
I think what makes you particularly unique is

563.text:
that the population is a manageable one

You do care about undergraduates in

this is one of the best things about liberal

the development of those undergraduates, and

that you can pull them into the

583.text:
And I'm sure as you go through the planning, as

by the authenticity of people across the campus

you are top-ranking in undergrad teaching

And I'd like to talk about a part of what

You attract some of the best-prepared
students in the world.

The questions is, what can you say about

About their values, about their
interests in helping others,

Because you are preparing those who will

and I think it gives you a wonderful
opportunity, but an awesome responsibility

633.text:
as you think about your graduates who
will lead the nation in many ways.

That we've got this responsibility not simply
to give them skills, but to help them think

644.text:
about their view of the world, their
relationship to others around the world,

650.text:
and particularly to people who have not had
the privileges of my middle class population,

658.text:
Not all, but clearly you are some of the most
privileged -- your students, in the world.

663.text:
And you are fortunate to be in
this setting and I commend you.

I simply say to you what I say to my

How do we think about the Dartmouth

I come from a campus that has
students from 150 countries.

Make no mistake about it, the students

to be far more disciplined

Far more disciplined -- whether they're

and looking in the mirror and this notion of

"How do we help students from all racial and

To excel, how do we set the

and learning environment to ensure that as many

of mind, who will appreciate what it means

Smart meaning excitement about ideas, smart

753.text:
in a refereed journal, or about

I said today to some of your colleagues that

but we're also strong in arts and humanities,

a wonderful facility by the way, I was taking

of finishing our $170 Million
dollar arts and humanities building.

You go to a production you're

You never leave theater at
UMBC happy, I promise you that.

Wait a minute, the students, the serious ones
-- Beckett, we talk Beckett a lot, and across,

so whether it's science or theatre,

Years ago my students of Asian descent
tended to be working in groups, and my black

815.text:
and white students tended to be talking
about the party from the night before.

And we were determined to change
that, to turn that around.

821.text:
And one of the things we did was to
help American students look at and think

826.text:
about how people from other parts
of the world view their education.

829.text:
I'll never forget having a focus group and
we had students from Russia, from China,

834.text:
from New York, from DC, and a young woman from
Jamaica and it was very clear that the students

841.text:
who had spent most of their lives in other
countries and came here when they were 13 or 14

845.text:
or whatever were just more serious
about the work, a little more intense,

849.text:
and I was trying to understand
why there were these differences.

854.text:
And one of the students from Jamaica said,

863.text:
but it seems to me that middle-class Americans
go to college thinking that it's Grade 13.

868.text: It is the next thing you do.

870.text:
So for you -- " She looked at her
friends, her American friends, she said,

874.text: "This is just the icing on the cake."

876.text:
She said, "But for me, if I don't excel, my
younger brothers and sisters may not eat.

885.text:
So it's not the icing on the
cake, it's the very bread of life.

890.text:
And it was -- there was this moment
of goose bumps, because she almost --

895.text:
she literally almost brought people to
tears because it was for her so serious

901.text: that she should work to be the very best.

905.text: And that moment was an exciting one

907.text:
because it sparked great conversation
about how we view education.

912.text: Why is it important to go to college?

914.text:
Is it simply about getting
a job and making money?

916.text: Is it about much more than that?

918.text: Is it about one's sense of moral identity?

921.text:
And it was fascinating that we
continue to have those conversations,

925.text:
and one of my recommendations to places
that are working on innovation is

928.text:
to not only have faculty and staff
thinking about who you are, your culture

935.text:
and what you want to become, but to have those
conversations with students, undergraduate

940.text:
and graduate students, and to listen
to the voices of those students.

943.text:
It's amazing how much I have
learned over the years.

946.text: I want you to think about it.

948.text:
First of all, much of what I say
today can be found in the articles,

952.text:
if you go to my webpage you'll see a number of
articles that a research team and I have worked

955.text:
on for years regarding our culture
and what has made the difference.

960.text:
We decided some years ago that we
could be much better than we were.

965.text:
That while the best students, often students
who had some international background

970.text:
and a few others were doing well, and everyone
knew if you wanted to go to med school

974.text:
in my state we were one of the places you'd come
to, it was very clear that minority students --

979.text:
particularly underrepresented black
and Hispanic were not doing well.

982.text:
And we decided to experiment, to start
a program, the Meyerhoff program,

987.text:
with the idea that we wanted to find the best
prepared students we could find in our state,

992.text:
be first in our state, and see if we
gave them support how well they could do.

998.text:
I went around the country looking for one
institution, predominantly white institution

1004.text:
that was producing even five
black kids a year who get PhDs.

1007.text: Could not find one, in the nation.

1009.text:
And what I found as I went to a lot of the
Ivies, a lot of the kids who started off

1014.text:
in pre-med and changed to
pre-law, business or whatever.

1017.text:
And I should tell you my report
from the National Academy of --

1020.text:
If you look at the report on underrepresentation
in science, that came out in the last year

1025.text:
with people from Harvard and MIT, [inaudible]
which is one of the Texas Institutions,

1031.text:
what we saw was it isn't surprising that only
20% of African-Americans and Hispanics begin

1038.text:
with a major in science or
engineering or graduate in those areas.

1042.text:
It is stunning that only 32% of whites who begin
with a major in science or engineering graduate

1048.text:
with a bachelor's in science and
engineering, and only 42% of Asian-Americans.

1052.text:
Now the first response is,
"Students aren't well-prepared."

1055.text:
Well, that is true for some, but other
researched showed the committee this:

1060.text:
The higher the SATs, and the larger
the number of AP credits in some areas,

1066.text:
and the more selective the
university, now listen carefully

1068.text:
because this is counterintuitive --
and the more selective the university,

1072.text:
the greater the probability the
student regardless of race who begins

1074.text: in science will leave it within a year or two.

1079.text:
Now, usually students will say,
"Well, I liked something else better."

1084.text:
Well, if you get an A in something else and a
C or D in science of course you like it better!

1088.text:
[Laughter] and if you've been valedictorian
in your high school, you're not going back

1090.text:
and saying, "I didn't do well
in science," we said this --

1093.text:
I said this to all of the
institute directors at NIH.

1097.text:
And I said, jokingly with my lawyer friends, and
many who start off pre-med become great lawyers.

1101.text:
That's the big joke, except
it's true, it really is.

1104.text:
And the lawyer for NIH came out afterwards and
she said, "I went to the most selective of all,

1110.text:
valedictorian, perfect SAT
and you just told my story."

1114.text:
And she said, "I've always
been embarrassed to admit it."

1116.text:
If you talk to American audiences and you ask
them the question, "How many of you know someone

1122.text:
who started off in pre-med, engineering or
any of those areas who changed their major?"

1127.text:
They do. And the point I made to NIH is this:
We're working to get the American public

1133.text:
to be more appreciative of the value of
science in our society, to be more supportive

1139.text:
of congress giving more money for
stem cell research in other areas.

1143.text:
If even the highest achieving Americans in
large numbers don't have successful experiences

1152.text:
in science, why would we
expect the average American

1157.text:
to be appreciative of the
need to support science?

1161.text:
And so, starting with the idea of wanting
our country to invest in science research

1167.text:
and stem areas, whether talking about for
healthcare or for energy and environmental

1172.text:
or for intelligence and defense, it
seems to me for the good of the country,

1177.text:
we need to think about the culture of teaching
and learning in science and engineering.

1183.text:
NSF calls the first year of
stem across institutions,

1187.text:
two-year and four-year institutions,
and "weed-out courses."

1192.text:
Now I've worked with some of the best liberal
arts colleges in New England, with presidents

1196.text: and deans of science, and I always say to them,

1200.text:
"You don't expect the majority of your students
who start in the first year of science to go

1204.text:
to the second year," and they would
say, "Why would you say that?"

1206.text:
I say this: go back and look at the first
year, whatever that is, for your campus,

1211.text:
the first year, the number of
seats, and then look at the number

1213.text: of seats in the second year group.

1215.text:
There is a big reduction because the
assumption is a certain percentage will leave.

1220.text:
Now I want to really commend a faculty
member here today, his name is John Cool,

1226.text:
he may not be here now, but John said no
campus -- I said -- here's the question.

1230.text:
What's the probability of a student
at your institution who begins

1234.text:
in science graduating with
a bachelor's in science?

1239.text:
And this was the first place I came -- I've been
to 50 or 60 institutions in the past few years

1245.text:
where he could show me a chart
where he had actually worked

1248.text: on the data himself to collect it.

1250.text: It was very impressive that he had done that.

1252.text:
Then I said, "now the next question
is, if they graduated in science,

1255.text:
did they at least have a B
average in the science courses?'

1258.text:
Because you can't get into grad school or think
about med school if you don't have at least B's

1263.text:
in those courses -- it's not enough to have a
3.0 overall, med schools, grad schools will look

1268.text:
at research you've done, but they're

1271.text:
clearly, and they want at least a B average

1274.text:
to go back and do that, but at least he was

1278.text:
with all of that is this: that any campus
that is serious as we have to become,

1283.text:
about helping students in
general to succeed in science,

1287.text:
needs to understand how students are doing by

1296.text:
Because what happens in one discipline,
biology, may be different from what happens

1300.text:
in mechanical engineering or what happens
in computer science and it's a challenge

1305.text:
for minorities; it's a challenge
for women in many areas,

1308.text: but it's a challenge for whites in general.

And so across this country the result
is this: only six percent of the degrees

1319.text:
of the bachelor's degrees in America
are in natural sciences and engineering.

1325.text:
And this is for a 24-year-olds, we're
talking about those with a degree, 6%.

1330.text:
In Europe it's almost 12%, and in some of
the Asian countries much higher than that.

Computer science is one of the most
glaring examples of a challenge we face:

1339.text:
according to the National Science
Foundation, we have a shortage

of about 50,000 bachelor's degrees in

And the head of computer sciences,

1355.text:
"the problem of underrepresentation" -- meaning
if you look at women and people of color

1360.text:
and people with disabilities, you're talking

1365.text:
"The problem of under-productivity
of degrees is inextricably linked

1371.text:
You can't get there in America unless we
find ways of increasing the number of women

1375.text:
and people of color in computer
science, as an example.

And so what we work to do on
our campus is to find ways

1382.text: to see how we might improve performance.

1385.text: And here are some of the lessons.

1387.text:
Building community among the
students makes a big difference.

1391.text:
Getting away from the cutthroat attitude
that I can't tell you what I know

1394.text:
because then your school would be higher than

If you asked any student on
your campus or mine at midterms,

1402.text: "how are you doing in a certain class?'

Whether that student got a D or an A
